title: Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes
descriptions:
Here is a 305-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes

This project proposes the development of a transdisciplinary research program, Topological Atlas, to map and analyze contemporary borderscapes as experienced by those who encounter them. The project challenges traditional cartographic representations of borders as fixed and impermeable, instead conceptualizing them as porous, shifting, and solidified entities that operate beyond legal frameworks. The Topological Atlas will employ a participative approach, utilizing digital technologies such as GIS and Google Earth to create a digital atlas that disrupts cartographic norms.

Through visual counter-geographies, the project will produce maps that represent seamless transitions between spaces, highlighting the experiences of migrants and security apparatuses. The research will adapt to situations of crisis, co-producing knowledge with individuals who have encountered borders in various contexts. By researching border areas beyond top-down perspectives, this project aims to develop a new understanding of borders as topological entities.

The research question guiding this project is: How can mapping be used to represent borders as topological entities through the experience of those who encounter them? By answering this question, the Topological Atlas will contribute to a deeper understanding of the complexities of contemporary borderscapes, informing academic inquiry, knowledge production, and the impact of knowledge on policy and practice. Ultimately, this project seeks to develop a new paradigm for mapping borders, one that prioritizes the experiences of those who navigate them.

Here is a 305-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes

This project proposes a transdisciplinary research program to develop a digital atlas that reimagines the representation of borders as topological entities. The Topological Atlas will challenge traditional cartographic norms by mapping borders as porous, shifting, and solidified entities that are experienced differently by various individuals and groups. Through a participative and visual counter-geographies approach, we will co-produce maps with migrants, security apparatus, and other stakeholders to represent the complex and dynamic nature of borders.

The atlas will utilize digital technologies, including GIS technology and Google Earth, to create seamless transitions between different spatial representations. By doing so, it will disrupt traditional cartographic norms and provide a new framework for understanding the operation of borders beyond legal frameworks. Our research will focus on situations of crisis, such as the formation of ISIS and the opening and closing of European borders, to demonstrate the atlas's ability to adapt to changing contexts.

The Topological Atlas aims to answer the question: "How can mapping be used to represent borders as topological entities through the experience of those who encounter them?" By exploring this question, we will develop a new conceptual framework for understanding borders as topological entities, rather than fixed lines on a map. This project will have significant implications for academic inquiry, knowledge production, and the impact of knowledge on society, particularly in the fields of geography, migration studies, and critical security studies. Ultimately, the Topological Atlas will provide a new tool for researchers, policymakers, and individuals to understand and intervene in the complex and dynamic landscape of contemporary borderscapes.

Here is a 305-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes

This proposal seeks funding for a transdisciplinary research program, "Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes," which aims to challenge traditional cartographic representations of borders by mapping them as complex, dynamic, and topological entities. The project focuses on the porosity, shifting nature, and solidification of borders, highlighting the dichotomy between openness for some and impenetrability for others. Through a participative and visual counter-geographies approach, we will develop a digital atlas that disrupts cartographic norms and represents borders from the perspective of migrants and security apparatuses.

Our methodology combines topology, digital technologies, and GIS technology, including Google Earth, to produce seamless transitions and innovative space representations. The project's objectives are to produce maps that reflect the experiences of those who encounter borders, and to develop a research model that adapts to situations of crisis. Our research will take a co-produced, visual, and adaptive approach, acknowledging the relationship between academic inquiry, knowledge production, and the impact of knowledge.

The proposed project addresses pressing issues related to the mobility of geopolitical territorial formations, the operation of borders beyond legal frameworks, and the variable enforcement of treaties. By mapping contemporary borderscapes, we will provide new insights into the complexities of border dynamics and their effects on individuals and communities. Ultimately, our project seeks to answer the question: How can mapping be used to represent borders as topological entities through the experience of those who encounter them?
